question: A P-i-C is:

choices.choice: The pilot who is competent to fly the aeroplane under all weather conditions
The Pilot who for the time being is in charge of the controls of the aeroplane
A pilot who is responsible for the operation and safety of the aeroplane during flight time.

explanation: The Pilot-in-Command (PIC) is the pilot responsible for the operation and safety of the aircraft during flight time. They have final authority over the flight and ensure compliance with aviation regulations, safeguarding the journey under all conditions.
subject: Regulations

question: Why PANS OPS are a separate document from the Annexes?

choices.choice: The procedures are outside of the scope of the SARPS
The procedure are too complicated for pilots to understand
The document is not relevant to air crew

explanation:
PANS OPS (Procedures for Air Navigation Services – Aircraft Operations) is a separate document from the Annexes because it provides detailed operational procedures and design criteria for flight operations that are not standardized in the ICAO Annexes, which focus on Standards and Recommended Practices (SARPs).

PANS documents are meant to support the SARPs by offering technical and implementation guidance rather than mandatory standards, allowing for flexibility in application by different states and regions​.
subject: Regulations

question: ARIWS stands for:

choices.choice: Automatic Runway Instrumented Weather Services
Autonomous Runway Incursion Warning System
Airborne Runway Instrument Warning System

explanation:
ARIWS (Autonomous Runway Incursion Warning System) is a system designed to help detect and warn against runway incursions by aircraft or vehicles on the runway. It provides real-time warnings to prevent collisions on runways by identifying situations where an aircraft or vehicle may be in a position that poses a danger to other aircraft during takeoff or landing.

This system operates autonomously, independent of air traffic control, by using sensors and surveillance technology to provide warnings directly to pilots and ground personnel.
subject: Regulations

question: A Control Area is:

choices.choice: defined area of airspace in which all controlled flights are provided with an Air Traffic Service
The confluence of airways adjacent to one or more aerodromes where ATC is provided to all air traffic
A portion of airspace (between defined altitudes) where it has been determined that an ATC service will be provided to all IFR traffic and some VFR traffic

explanation: A Control Area (CTA) is a volume of controlled airspace that starts at a specified lower altitude and extends upwards to a higher limit, where Air Traffic Control (ATC) services are provided to all IFR flights and some VFR flights. This ensures safe separation and management of air traffic in congested or complex airspaces, particularly around aerodromes and busy flight routes. The specific altitude limit varies depending on the geographical area and airspace requirements.
subject: Regulations

question: The document ‘Procedures for Air Navigation Services – Air Traffic Management’ (PANS-ATM) is also commonly known by its IACO document number. What is the document number?

choices.choice: Doc 8168
Doc 4444
Doc 7333

explanation:
Doc 4444, titled “Procedures for Air Navigation Services – Air Traffic Management” (PANS-ATM), is a crucial document from ICAO that outlines procedures for the efficient and safe management of air traffic services. It includes protocols for airspace management, coordination between ATC units, and ensures the implementation of best practices in air traffic control.

This manual supports ICAO Annex 11, which sets the standards for air traffic services. It serves to maintain global consistency in air traffic operations and is an essential reference for ATC personnel worldwide.
subject: Regulations

question: Who is responsible for the issuing of clearance to achieve the safe and expeditions flow of a traffic to aircraft on the maneuvering area and to prevent collisions between aircraft and obstructions on the movement area?

choices.choice: The aerodrome Controller
The approach Controller
The Ground Controller

explanation: The Aerodrome Controller is responsible for issuing clearances to ensure the safe and efficient flow of traffic on the maneuvering area (runways and taxiways). This includes preventing collisions between aircraft and obstructions on the movement area and coordinating aircraft and vehicle operations within their area of responsibility.
subject: Regulations

question: What Annex to the Chicago Convention covers ‘Facilitation’?

choices.choice: Annex 6
Annex 9
Annex 15

explanation: Annex 9 focuses on facilitation of international air transport, addressing efficient border control procedures, customs, immigration, public health, and other formalities to streamline travel and cargo processes while maintaining security and compliance with international standards.
subject: Regulations

question: What is ICAO?

choices.choice: An organization only permitted to make recommendations, which are not binding on member states.
An organization of civil aviation operators, limited to 33 members
A specialized agency related to the United Nations

explanation: The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) is a specialized agency of the United Nations. It was established in 1944 by the Chicago Convention to manage and promote the safe and orderly development of international civil aviation. ICAO develops Standards and Recommended Practices (SARPs) for aviation safety, security, efficiency, and environmental protection, which member states incorporate into their national regulations.
subject: Regulations

question: Two aircraft are departing from a reporting point defined by an NDB. What is the minimum track separation required before one aircraft would be permitted to climb/descend through the other aircraft’s level?

choices.choice: 30° and a distance of 15 nm or more
15° and a distance of 15 km or more
30° and a distance of 15 km or more

explanation:
Track separation involves ensuring lateral spacing between aircraft by assigning specific tracks that meet a minimum angle and distance requirement based on the navigation aid used. The parameters are:

  • VOR: Track divergence 15°; distance 15 NM.
  • NDB: Track divergence 30°; distance 15 NM.
  • DR Fix: Track divergence 45°; distance 15 NM.
subject: Regulations

question: What does the structure of ICAO consists of?

choices.choice: An assembly, Council, Secretariat, committees and commissions.
A Council; a Secretariat and committees and commissions.
A ruling council of a small number of permanent states (like the UN security council) with committees and commission reporting to the Council.

explanation:
The structure of ICAO consists of an Assembly, a Council, a Secretariat, and specialized committees and commissions.

  • The Assembly is the sovereign body, composed of all member states, meeting triennially to establish policies.
  • The Council, a permanent body elected by the Assembly, ensures adherence to ICAO’s strategic objectives.
  • The Secretariat, led by the Secretary General, manages ICAO’s day-to-day operations through specialized bureaus.
  • Committees and commissions handle specific technical and policy-related functions.
subject: Regulations

question: Trip fuel, which shall be the amount of fuel required to enable the aeroplane to fly:

choices.choice: from take-off, until landing at the destination aerodrome
from take-off or the point of in-flight re-planning, until landing at the destination aerodrome.
from take-off, until landing at the destination aerodrome, including taxi fuel

explanation:
“The amount of fuel required to enable the aeroplane to fly from take-off or the point of in-flight re-planning, until landing at the destination aerodrome.”

Key Points:

  • Trip fuel includes fuel needed for climb, cruise, descent, and approach to the planned destination.
  • It excludes taxi fuel (calculated separately).
  • It accounts for re-planning if an in-flight reroute occurs.
subject: Regulations

question: Factors affecting night vision are:

choices.choice: Alcohol, smoking, cabin altitude above 8000' and age
Alcohol, smoking, cabin altitude above 5000' and instrument lights
Alcohol, smoking, age and lack of vitamin D

explanation:
• Alcohol: Impairs visual acuity and depth perception, making it harder to see clearly at night.
  • Smoking: Reduces oxygen levels in the body, which impacts the eyes’ ability to adapt to low light conditions.
  • Cabin altitude above 8000 feet: Can lead to hypoxia, reducing oxygen supply to the eyes, thereby diminishing night vision.
  • Age: Older individuals may experience a decrease in the effectiveness of their rods (the part of the eye responsible for night vision) over time.
subject: Regulations

question: When do PANS-ATM procedures absolve pilots from the responsibility for terrain avoidance?

choices.choice: Never
When under radar vectoring
During take off and landing.

explanation: According to PANS-ATM (8.9.4.1), radar controllers are responsible for ensuring terrain clearance during the initial and intermediate approach phases when radar vectoring is provided. This responsibility includes the safe separation of the aircraft from terrain while the aircraft is under radar control. However, once the aircraft is cleared for final approach and resumes own navigation, the responsibility for terrain avoidance transitions to the pilot.
subject: Regulations

question: Vitamins are essential for good night vision, therefore:

choices.choice: Pilots should take excess intake of vitamin A to improve night vision significantly
Pilots should take balanced diet containing sufficient vitamin A)
Vitamin A deficiency does not matter, so long the pilot has adequate vitamin D intake.

explanation: Pilots should maintain a balanced diet with sufficient vitamin A, as it is crucial for good night vision. Vitamin A helps the retina adjust to low light, which is essential for pilots. Excessive intake does not significantly improve vision, and vitamin D does not affect night vision. A deficiency in vitamin A can impair night vision.
subject: Regulations

question: What is the relevance of the OCH for a precision approach?

choices.choice: It is the MDH if the glide path information is lost
It is the lowest height at which a missed approach must be initiated
It is the height at which an aircraft correctly positioned on the glide must obtain the visual minima to land

explanation: The OCH (Obstacle Clearance Height) represents the minimum height required to ensure sufficient obstacle clearance during a precision approach. If the visual reference needed to continue the approach is not established by this height, a missed approach must be initiated to ensure safety and prevent collisions with obstacles.
subject: Regulations

question: When converging at approximately the same altitude:

choices.choice: balloons shall give way to hang gliders
aeroplanes towing gliders shall give way to balloons
balloons shall give way to gliders

explanation:
The right-of-way rules for aircraft when converging at the same altitude are as follows:

  • Power-driven heavier-than-air aircraft (aeroplanes) shall give way to airships, gliders, and balloons.
  • Power-driven lighter-than-air aircraft (airships) shall give way to gliders and balloons.
  • Gliders shall give way to balloons.
  • Power-driven aircraft shall give way to aircraft towing other aircraft or objects​.

In the case of aeroplanes towing gliders, the towing aircraft must give way to balloons, consistent with the overall priority system.
subject: Regulations

question: Where traffic is flying in an established traffic pattern at an aerodrome where ATC is provided (a controlled aerodrome), who is responsible for collision avoidance??

choices.choice: It depends upon the class of airspace
The aerodrome controller
The pilots of the aeroplanes

explanation: When operating at a controlled aerodrome, pilots are responsible for collision avoidance within the traffic pattern, even though air traffic control (ATC) provides separation services. Pilots are still expected to maintain vigilance, follow the correct procedures, and avoid other aircraft in the vicinity. ATC is tasked with providing separation and guidance, but the final responsibility for seeing and avoiding other aircraft lies with the pilots, who must visually scan for traffic and react to any potential conflict.
subject: Regulations

question: Normal AOM RVR is 300m, Restricted AOM shall be:
subject: Regulations

question: Enroute flt levels are on:

choices.choice: QNE
QNH
QFE

explanation:
Enroute flight levels are based on QNE, which is the standard atmospheric pressure setting of 1013.25 hPa (hectopascals). This is used for aircraft navigation above a certain altitude (typically above 3,000 feet) to ensure consistent pressure readings, regardless of local weather conditions.

In contrast:

  • QNH is the pressure setting adjusted to local sea level, used for altimeter settings during approach and landing.
  • QFE is the pressure at the aerodrome level, used for measuring heights above the aerodrome itself, particularly for operations near the ground.
subject: Regulations

question: What is the International Aeronautical VHF Distress and Calling frequency?
explanation:
The International Aeronautical VHF Distress and Calling frequency is 121.500 MHz. This frequency is used for emergency communication between aircraft and air traffic control or other aircraft, and is monitored globally for distress calls.

  • 123.450 MHz is commonly used for general aviation communication, but is not a distress frequency.
  • 406.000 MHz is the frequency used by 406 MHz ELTs (Emergency Locator Transmitters), which are used to transmit distress signals from aircraft in an emergency, but it is not the direct calling frequency used for VHF communication.
subject: Regulations

question: You are flying in VMC and you suffer a communications failure. What are you required to o

choices.choice: Land immediately
Continue to fly in VMC and land at the nearest suitable aerodrome
Turn around and head back to the aerodrome of departure

explanation: In the event of a communications failure while flying in Visual Meteorological Conditions (VMC), the pilot is required to continue flying in VMC and land at the nearest suitable aerodrome. This is because, in VMC, the pilot can navigate and land visually, ensuring safety without the need for radio communication.
subject: Regulations

question: If you are flying in IMC and you suffer a communication failure, which of the following is a correct course of action?

choices.choice: Proceed in accordance with the flight plan as filed
Proceed in accordance with the current flight plan(the flight plan as cleared by ATC and any re-clearance subsequently obtained).
Turn around and go home

explanation:
If you are flying in Instrument Meteorological Conditions (IMC) and suffer a communications failure, the correct course of action is to proceed in accordance with the current flight plan (which is the flight plan as cleared by ATC and any re-clearance subsequently obtained).

This means:

  • The aircraft should continue the flight following the cleared route, speed, and altitude.
  • If radar services are provided, the aircraft should maintain the last assigned level and speed for a specific period (7 minutes in radar-covered airspace).
  • If in areas without radar, the aircraft should maintain the last assigned speed and level, or the minimum flight altitude, for a longer period (20 minutes) and then adjust the route based on the flight plan.
subject: Regulations

question: What are the objectives of an ATC clearance?

choices.choice: To see how accurately the pilot can read the clearance back and test if he can spot errors
To give route and altitude specific information when different from that flight planned
Collision avoidance and air traffic flow management

explanation: Collision Avoidance and Air Traffic Flow Management: The clearance provides specific instructions to the pilot for safe separation from other aircraft, ensuring proper traffic flow in the airspace. This minimizes the risk of mid-air collisions and helps manage the flow of air traffic efficiently.
subject: Regulations

question: Capillaries:

choices.choice: Facilitate oxygen/carbon dioxide exchange
Are the largest vessels carrying blood
Control heart beats

explanation:
Capillaries:

  • Facilitate oxygen/carbon dioxide exchange: Capillaries are the smallest blood vessels in the body and play a key role in exchanging gases like oxygen and carbon dioxide between the blood and tissues. Their thin walls allow for efficient diffusion of gases and nutrients at the cellular level​.

The other options are incorrect because:

  • Capillaries are not the largest vessels (that would be arteries).
  • Capillaries do not control heartbeats; that function is managed by the heart’s electrical conduction system (like the sinoatrial node).
subject: Regulations

question: An instrument approach has:

choices.choice: Three segments
Five segments
Six segments

explanation:
An instrument approach procedure consists of five segments:

  1. The Arrival Segment or Route: This segment includes the arrival route to the initial approach fix (IAF), which may involve enroute navigation.
  2. The Initial Segment: It aligns the aircraft with the approach, typically from the IAF to the intermediate fix (IF).
  3. The Intermediate Segment: This segment connects the initial approach to the final approach, where the aircraft descends to the final approach altitude.
  4. The Final Segment: This is the final leg of the approach, guiding the aircraft towards the runway for landing.
  5. The Missed Approach Segment and Procedure: This segment outlines the procedure if the aircraft cannot land, including the necessary maneuvers to re-enter the enroute phase or to a holding pattern.
subject: Regulations

question: What is the principle objective of a rescue and fire flighting service?

choices.choice: To minimize the damage cause by fire
To extinguish any with minimum delay
To save lives

explanation: The principal objective of a rescue and fire fighting service (RFFS) is to save lives. While minimizing damage caused by fire and extinguishing fires are important, the safety of people is the top priority. The service ensures a rapid response to emergencies to protect lives, followed by reducing damage.
subject: Regulations

question: Ascending order of stress is:

choices.choice: Family death, divorce, marriage, mortgage
Mortgage, marriage, family death, divorce
Mortgage, marriage, divorce, family death

explanation:
Pilots suffering from life stresses should be aware that this can affect their concentration and performance when at the controls of an aircraft.

The descending order in which the factors affect a person are:

NOTE: THE QUESTION ASKS ASCENDING 

death of spouse/child,

divorce,

marital separation,

death of a close family member,

injury/illness,

marriage,

loss of job,

retirement,

pregnancy,

sexual problems,

birth,

change of financial status,

siblings leaving home,

change of eating habits,

change of residence,

loan/debt/mortgage,

vacations and minor violations of law
subject: Regulations

question: Who is responsible for the issue of a certificate of airworthiness?

choices.choice: ICAO
The DGCA
The authority of State of Registration

explanation:
The authority of the State of Registration is responsible for issuing the Certificate of Airworthiness. According to ICAO Annex 8: Airworthiness of Aircraft, the State of Registration is required to ensure that aircraft meet airworthiness standards and are issued this certificate.

While in India, the DGCA (Directorate General of Civil Aviation) plays a regulatory role in overseeing compliance with these standards, the certificate itself is issued by the State of Registration based on ICAO’s guidelines.
subject: Regulations

question: While facing turbulent weather, a pilot reduces speed to:

choices.choice: Avoid stalling
Achieve better maneuroability
Avoid structural damage

explanation: When facing turbulent weather, pilots reduce speed to minimize the forces acting on the aircraft and avoid structural damage. Flying at an excessive speed during turbulence can increase the stress on the aircraft’s structure, potentially leading to damage.
subject: Regulations

question: Circadian Circle represents:

choices.choice: our level of alertness throughout the day
our level of competence to undertake a challenging job
our level of incompetence after the peak is achieved in a career

explanation: The circadian circle refers to the natural, internal process that regulates the sleep-wake cycle and repeats roughly every 24 hours. It affects alertness and performance levels at different times of the day.
subject: Regulations

question: Some one is calling you using a language which you cannot understand. You will indicate this by transmitting:

choices.choice: Can not comply
Unable to comply
Can not

explanation: In aviation phraseology, when a message is received in a language that cannot be understood, the standard ICAO response is “Can not”. This phrase is explicitly designed to minimize confusion and ensure clear communication, especially in international contexts where language barriers might exist. This is in alignment with ICAO’s Manual of Radiotelephony (Doc 9432) guidelines for handling such scenarios.
subject: Regulations

question: An aircraft electing to change the conduct of its flight from IFR to VFR hall, if a flight plan was submitted, notify the appropriate ATS unit specifically by transmitting:

choices.choice: Cancelling my IFR flight plan
Cancelling my IFR flight
Cancelling my IFR plan

explanation:
The appropriate phraseology for an aircraft changing its flight rules from IFR to VFR is “Cancelling my IFR flight”. This phrase complies with ICAO Annex 2 guidelines, which state that the pilot must:

  1. Notify the ATS unit specifically about the cancellation of IFR flight compliance.
  2. Provide any required updates to the flight plan for continued VFR operations.
subject: Regulations

question: An aircraft is flying under instrument Flight Rules in area where the visibility is unlimited and the sky is clear, when it totally loses radio communications. the procedure to be followed is:

choices.choice: land on closest appropriate aerodrome, then advise Air Traffic Services of landing.
continue flight onto destination, complying with last received clearances then with filed flight plan
descend to En-route Minimum Safe Altitude and join closest airfield open to IFR operations

explanation:
If the aircraft is flying IFR in VMC conditions and experiences radio communication failure (RCF), the correct procedure as per ICAO Annex 2 is to:

  1. Continue to fly in VMC conditions.
  2. Land at the nearest suitable aerodrome where a safe landing can be made.
  3. Inform the appropriate ATS unit of the landing as soon as possible.
subject: Regulations

question: QNH at Mumbai is 1009. TL at Mumbai will be:

choices.choice: FL 45
FL 50
FL 55

explanation:
If the QNH is less than 1013 hPa, the Transition Level (TL) becomes FL55.
If the QNH is greater than 1013 hPa, the Transition Level (TL) remains FL50.
Given Data:
QNH at Mumbai = 1009 hPa
Transition Altitude (TA) is 4000 feet.
Applying the Rule:
Since the QNH is 1009 hPa, which is less than 1013 hPa, according to the rule:

The Transition Level (TL) becomes FL55.
Conclusion:
At Mumbai, with QNH = 1009 hPa, the Transition Level (TL) will be FL55.
subject: Regulations

question: To which aircraft is a flight information service (FIS) provided?

choices.choice: Only aircraft in receipt of ATC
All controlled flight from engine start to final shut gown
All aircraft in receipt of an ATC service or known to ATC which are likely to be affected by the information

explanation:
Flight Information Service (FIS) is provided to all aircraft under the following conditions:

  1. Aircraft in receipt of ATC services: Aircraft receiving active air traffic control services.
  2. Known to ATC: Aircraft that are not necessarily under active ATC service but are known to air traffic control and may benefit from the information, such as weather updates, route changes, or traffic advisories.
  3. Likely to be affected by the information: This ensures safety by keeping relevant aircraft informed, even if they are not under direct ATC guidance.
subject: Regulations

question: What type of airspace is normally established at the confluence of ATS routes in the vicinity of one or more major aerodrome?

choices.choice: Terminal Control Area (TMA)
Control Zone (CTR)
Special Rules Area (SRA)

explanation: A Terminal Control Area (TMA) is typically established at the confluence of ATS routes near major aerodromes. It is designed to manage aircraft approaching and departing from busy airports. The TMA is a controlled airspace, ensuring separation and safe handling of aircraft within the vicinity of a major aerodrome, often covering a larger area than the airport’s Control Zone (CTR).
subject: Regulations

question: Hypoxic hyoxia is

choices.choice: The result of low oxygen levels in the bloodstream
The result of low hemoglobin
An inability of the cells of the body to use the oxygen available

explanation:
Hypoxic hyoxia occurs when there is a lack of oxygen in the blood due to factors like insufficient atmospheric oxygen, reduced barometric pressure, or issues with lung function. It specifically refers to the inadequate oxygenation of the blood, which can result in impaired oxygen delivery to tissues and organs.

To clarify the other options:

  • Low hemoglobin refers to anemic hypoxia, not hypoxic hyoxia, where the problem lies in the transport capability of oxygen due to low hemoglobin levels.
  • An inability of the cells to use the oxygen available describes histotoxic hypoxia, where tissues cannot utilize oxygen effectively, typically due to toxins like cyanide.
subject: Regulations

question: You see yellow runway edge lights, what does this mean?

choices.choice: You have run into the stop way
They have run out of the normal colour bulbs
You are within 600m of the end of the runway or have less then one third of the runway remaining

explanation: Yellow runway edge lights, known as Runway End Identifier Lights (REIL), are typically used to indicate the last 600 meters or one-third of the runway, providing pilots with a visual cue that they are approaching the end of the runway. This helps pilots in situations where they need to make a decision to abort a takeoff or landing, as they are running out of runway.
subject: Regulations

question: What is the Annex of the Chicago Convention that covers SAR?

choices.choice: Annex 14
Annex 12
Annex 16

explanation:
Annex 12 provides the international standards and recommended practices for the planning and provision of search and rescue (SAR) services to assist aircraft in distress, ensuring that aircraft and their crews can be safely located and rescued in a timely manner.

  • Annex 14 deals with Aerodromes.
  • Annex 16 addresses Environmental Protection related to aviation.
subject: Regulations

question: The minimum safest altitude that the aircraft can descent below the transition altitude within 25 NMs of an aerodrome area is given by:

choices.choice: MSA
MOEA
MORA

explanation:
The Minimum Safe Altitude (MSA) is the lowest altitude that provides adequate clearance above obstacles or terrain within a specified distance (often 25 NM) of an aerodrome. This altitude ensures the aircraft maintains a safe distance from ground features while descending below the transition altitude.

  • MOEA (Minimum Obstruction Enroute Altitude): Ensures safe clearance over obstacles while enroute, but is not specific to the aerodrome area.
  • MORA (Minimum Off-Route Altitude): A general term referring to the lowest altitude to ensure obstacle clearance along an off-route flight path.
subject: Regulations

question: Presbyopia is also known as:

choices.choice: Short sightedness
Cross sightedness
Long sightedness

explanation: Presbyopia is a condition associated with aging, where the eye’s ability to focus on nearby objects diminishes. This typically leads to difficulty reading or seeing close objects clearly, a characteristic of long-sightedness (hyperopia). Unlike short-sightedness (myopia) or cross-sightedness (astigmatism), presbyopia is a natural part of aging, typically beginning around age 40.
subject: Regulations

question: If you are intercepted by a military aircraft over foreign territory, on what frequency should you attempt to speak to the military pilot?

choices.choice: The ATC frequency in use
121.500MHz (the VHF distress and calling frequency)
No specific frequency. Try the lot until get contact

explanation: In the event that you are intercepted by a military aircraft over foreign territory, you should initially attempt to contact the aircraft on 121.500 MHz, which is the international distress and emergency frequency. This frequency is monitored by both civilian and military aircraft, making it the most likely means of establishing communication.
subject: Regulations

question: You are carrying out an instrument approach to land at Mumbai international. You are IMC at FL 70. The radar controller tells you set the Mumbai QNH 1007 and described to and maintain 4500ft. The transition level is FL50. What do you do?

choices.choice: Tell the radar controller that you cannot accept his clearance as you are above the transition level
Level 1013 set until at FL50 then set 1007 and descend to 4500ft
Set 1007 immediately and advise leaving 7000ft for 4500ft

explanation:
Set 1007 immediately and advise leaving 7000ft for 4500ft.

Here’s why:

  • The transition level is FL50, meaning you should be operating in flight levels above FL50 and in altitudes below FL50. The QNH 1007 given by the radar controller should be set immediately, as you are below FL50.
  • While descending from FL70 to 4500ft, it’s important to adjust the altimeter to 1007 QNH as soon as you are descending below FL50, as per the altitude setting requirements in the region.
  • You should also inform the radar controller that you’re leaving 7000ft for 4500ft, ensuring clear communication.
subject: Regulations

question: Which of the following is NOT an approved method of radar identification using SSR?

choices.choice: Squawk handover from another radar controller
Track observation and position reports
Use of the IDENT function

explanation:
• Squawk handover from another radar controller and Use of the IDENT function are both valid methods of radar identification using Secondary Surveillance Radar (SSR). When a radar controller receives an aircraft’s squawk code from another controller, or if the aircraft uses the IDENT function to make its position clearer, it helps establish radar identification.
  • Track observation and position reports, however, is not a method used for radar identification via SSR. These methods are typically used with primary radar or as supplementary information to verify an aircraft’s identity, but they don’t directly involve SSR methods.
subject: Regulations

question: What information is contained in an AIC?

choices.choice: Major changes to Search and Rescue facilities
Information that does not qualify for inclusion in the AIP
A better printed version of a NOTAM

explanation: An Aeronautical Information Circular (AIC) contains important information that is of a temporary nature or does not meet the criteria for inclusion in the Aeronautical Information Publication (AIP). This may include updates on issues like safety procedures, changes to airspace structures, or temporary operational measures, including Search and Rescue facilities, but typically not on a permanent basis.
subject: Regulations

question: Who is responsible when damage is caused by an aeroplane to persons or property on the ground?

choices.choice: The Operator
The pilot usually flying or at the controls when the incident happened
The commander is responsible providing that no other person can be held responsible

explanation: Under international aviation law and various national regulations, the operator of an aircraft is generally responsible for damage caused to persons or property on the ground. This includes ensuring safe operation and compensating for any damages resulting from incidents. While the commander may be liable in certain cases, the operator holds the primary responsibility. In cases of negligence or non-compliance, both the operator and the commander may be held accountable.
subject: Regulations

question: ATIS is normally provided

choices.choice: to replace the FSS
to relieve frequency congestion
for the rapid updating weather forecasts

explanation: ATIS (Automatic Terminal Information Service) is provided primarily to reduce frequency congestion by broadcasting routine weather and operational information to pilots. This allows pilots to obtain necessary information before contacting Air Traffic Control (ATC), ensuring that ATC frequencies are not overloaded with repetitive requests. ATIS helps improve efficiency and reduces the workload of air traffic controllers.
subject: Regulations

question: “ASDA” (Acceleration Stop Distance Available) is:

choices.choice: The length of the take-off run available plus the length of the clearway
The length of the take-off run available plus the length of the stopway (if stopway is provided)
The length of the runway plus the length of stopway available (if stopway provided)

explanation:
The length of the take-off run available plus the length of the stopway (if stopway is provided).

ASDA (Acceleration Stop Distance Available) is the distance required for an aircraft to accelerate from a standstill to the decision speed and, if necessary, abort the takeoff and stop within a safe distance.
subject: Regulations
